snippet: A civil racketeering lawsuit was sealed because documents revealed that one of the principals had a criminal past and had helped prosecutors convict dangerous criminals.
abstract: Civil racketeering lawsuit that was sealed because documents it contained revealed that one of the principals had a criminal past and had helped prosecutors convict dangerous criminals, raises serious questions about court secrecy; some of the lawyers and judges involved believe that filing, accusing a group of people associated with a New York investment firm of stealing millions of dollars from investors, was reckless and unethical, while others cast the lawyer Frederick M Oberlander as an aggressive advocate on behalf of fraud victims.
lead_paragraph: A civil racketeering lawsuit was sealed because documents revealed that one of the principals had a criminal past and had helped prosecutors convict dangerous criminals.

headline.seo: Fraud Case Challenges Secrecy of Man’s Past as Criminal and Cooperating Witness
headline.main: By Revealing Man’s Past, Lawyer Tests Court Secrecy
